DataElement.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant brain and spinal cord tumor that arises from glial cells (astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, ependymal cells).  Tumors that arise from astrocytes are called astrocytic tumors or astrocytomas.  Tumors that arise from oligodendrocytes are called oligodendroglial tumors.  Tumors that arise from ependymal cells are called ependymomas. -- 2004_A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest._Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time._A benign or malignant brain and spinal cord tumor that arises from glial cells (astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, ependymal cells).  Tumors that arise from astrocytes are called astrocytic tumors or astrocytomas.  Tumors that arise from oligodendrocytes are called oligodendroglial tumors.  Tumors that arise from ependymal cells are called ependymomas. -- 2004_A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Tumors that arise from astrocytes are called astrocytic tumors or astrocytomas.  Tumors that arise from oligodendrocytes are called oligodendroglial tumors.  Tumors that arise from ependymal cells are called ependymomas. -- 2004_A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest._Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant brain and spinal cord tumor that arises from glial cells (astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, ependymal cells).  Tumors that arise from astrocytes are called astrocytic tumors or astrocytomas.  Tumors that arise from oligodendrocytes are called oligodendroglial tumors.  Tumors that arise from ependymal cells are called ependymomas. -- 2004:A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant brain and spinal cord tumor that arises from glial cells (astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, ependymal cells). Tumors that arise from astrocytes are called astrocytic tumors or astrocytomas. Tumors that arise from oligodendrocytes are called oligodendroglial tumors. Tumors that arise from ependymal cells are called ependymomas.
A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

Property.preferredDefinition: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Curated for The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) by request of L.Dillon 4/2011 sw

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant brain and spinal cord tumor that arises from glial cells (astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, ependymal cells).  Tumors that arise from astrocytes are called astrocytic tumors or astrocytomas.  Tumors that arise from oligodendrocytes are called oligodendroglial tumors.  Tumors that arise from ependymal cells are called ependymomas. -- 2004_A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to the accumulation of glial cells encircling vessels in a tissue specimen.

Concepts.definition: A change in the amino acid residue at position 12 in the GTPase KRas protein where glycine has been replaced by tryptophan.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to the accumulation of glial cells encircling neurons in a tissue specimen.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding that refers to the accumulation of glial cells encircling neurons in a tissue specimen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to the accumulation of glial cells encircling neurons in a tissue specimen.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding that refers to the accumulation of glial cells encircling neurons in a tissue specimen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to delicate vascular channel formations.  It is characterized by the formation of arborizing and curving capillaries.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding that refers to delicate vascular channel formations.  It is characterized by the formation of arborizing and curving capillaries.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to the intraluminal hyperplasia of endothelial cells, encircling the entire lumen.

Concepts.definition: Intraluminal hyperplasia of endothelial cells, encircling the entire lumen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to microvascular proliferation that resembles glomeruloid structures.  It is seen in gliomas.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding that refers to microvascular proliferation that resembles glomeruloid structures.  It is seen in gliomas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The main type of cell forming the lining of blood and lymph vessels and the inner layer of the endocardium. SYN endotheliocyte.: Hypertrophy; the abnormal enlargement of a body part or organ.

Concepts.definition: The main type of cell forming the lining of blood and lymph vessels and the inner layer of the endocardium.
Abnormal enlargement of a body part or organ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to the presence of ectopic gray matter in a tissue sample.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding that refers to the presence of ectopic gray matter in a tissue sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to the presence of ectopic white matter in a tissue sample.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding that refers to the presence of ectopic white matter in a tissue sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to the replacement of a group of one type of epithelial cells (e.g., glandular epithelial cells) to another type of epithelial cells (e.g., squamous epithelial cells).

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding that refers to the replacement of a group of one type of epithelial cells (e.g., glandular epithelial cells) to another type of epithelial cells (e.g., squamous epithelial cells).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neoplastic astrocyte characterized by the presence of an atypical nucleus (large, irregular, or hyperchromatic), scant amount of cytoplasm, and cell processes that contribute to the formation of a fibrillary matrix.

Concepts.definition: A neoplastic astrocyte characterized by the presence of an atypical nucleus (large, irregular, or hyperchromatic), scant amount of cytoplasm, and cell processes that contribute to the formation of a fibrillary matrix.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathologic astrocyte in which the cell body swells and contains glial filaments and an eccentric nucleus; seen particularly in demyelinating and neoplastic conditions.

Concepts.definition: A pathologic astrocyte in which the cell body swells and contains glial filaments and an eccentric nucleus; seen particularly in demyelinating and neoplastic conditions.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding referring to the presence of a cellular infiltrate that is composed of non-neoplastic or neoplastic lymphocytes in a tissue sample.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding referring to the presence of a cellular infiltrate that is composed of non-neoplastic or neoplastic lymphocytes in a tissue sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding indicating tissue infiltration by non-neoplastic or neoplastic histiocytes.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding indicating tissue infiltration by non-neoplastic or neoplastic histiocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to the transformation or replacement of a group of non-mesenchymal cells into osseous, cartilagenous, or lipomatous cells.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding that refers to the transformation or replacement of a group of non-mesenchymal cells into osseous, cartilagenous, or lipomatous cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term that refers to the microarchitectural environment and mineralization.

Concepts.definition: A term that refers to the microarchitectural environment and mineralization.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Tiny deposits of calcium in tissue.  In the breast they can be seen using mammography, and if found in clusters may be indicative of breast cancer.

Concepts.definition: Tiny deposits of calcium in tissue.  In the breast they can be seen using mammography, and if found in clusters may be indicative of breast cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tiny cyst that is usually identified by microscopic examination in a tissue specimen.

Concepts.definition: A tiny cyst that is usually identified by microscopic examination in a tissue specimen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neoplastic gemistocytic astrocyte characterized by a diminutive size, a single, eccentric nucleus, and a cytoplasmic droplet of eosinophilic material.

Concepts.definition: A neoplastic gemistocytic astrocyte characterized by a diminutive size, a single, eccentric nucleus, and a cytoplasmic droplet of eosinophilic material.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A large cell-like structure formed by the joining together of two or more cells.  The plural is syncytia.

Concepts.definition: An abnormally large cell that contains multiple nuclei and an abundant amount of cytoplasm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding referring to the presence of multiple foci of serpentine necrosis and glial cell perivascular pseudopalisading in a glioma.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding referring to the presence of multiple foci of serpentine necrosis and glial cell perivascular pseudopalisading in a glioma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic architectural pattern characterized by the presence of proliferating non-neoplastic or neoplastic cells forming single or multiple nodules within a lesion.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic architectural pattern characterized by the presence of proliferating non-neoplastic or neoplastic cells forming single or multiple nodules within a lesion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A well-differentiated (WHO grade II), diffusely infiltrating neuroglial tumor, typically located in the cerebral hemispheres.  It is composed predominantly of cells which morphologically resemble oligodendroglia. The neoplastic cells have rounded homogeneous nuclei and, on paraffin sections, a swollen, clear cytoplasm ('honeycomb' appearance). (Adapted from WHO)

Concepts.definition: A well-differentiated (WHO grade 2), diffusely infiltrating neuroglial tumor, typically located in the cerebral hemispheres.  It is composed predominantly of cells which morphologically resemble oligodendroglia. The neoplastic cells have rounded homogeneous nuclei and, on paraffin sections, a swollen, clear cytoplasm ('honeycomb' appearance). (Adapted from WHO)

PermissibleValues.value: Oligodendroglioma-like component with perinuclear cytoplasmic halos
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Oligodendroglioma-Like Component with Perinuclear Cytoplasmic Halos Present

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Oligodendroglioma-Like Component with Perinuclear Cytoplasmic Halos Present
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding referring to the presence of a cellular infiltrate that is composed of cells with perinuclear cytoplasmic halos, resembling oligodendrocytes.

Concepts.longName: Oligodendroglioma-Like Component with Perinuclear Cytoplasmic Halos Present
Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding referring to the presence of a cellular infiltrate that is composed of cells with perinuclear cytoplasmic halos, resembling oligodendrocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding referring to the presence of a vacuolated area that surrounds the nucleus.  It results from nuclear shrinking.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding referring to the presence of a vacuolated area that surrounds the nucleus.  It results from nuclear shrinking.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding referring to an acute inflammatory infiltrate that is composed of polymorphonuclear cells.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding referring to an acute inflammatory infiltrate that is composed of polymorphonuclear cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant cell that is characterized by the presence of a small nucleus and scant amount of cytoplasm.  It may be epithelial, lymphoid, neuroepithelial, or mesenchymal in origin.: The largest and most numerous neuroglial cells in the brain and spinal cord. Astrocytes are irregularly shaped with many long processes, including those with "end feet" which form the glial (limiting) membrane and directly and indirectly contribute to the blood brain barrier. They regulate the extracellular ionic and chemical environment, and "reactive astrocytes" (along with microglia) respond to injury. Astrocytes have high- affinity transmitter uptake systems, voltage-dependent and transmitter-gated ion channels, and can release transmitter, but their role in signaling (as in many other functions) is not well understood. (MeSH)

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant cell that is characterized by the presence of a small nucleus and scant amount of cytoplasm.  It may be epithelial, lymphoid, neuroepithelial, or mesenchymal in origin.
A heterogeneous group of specialized neuroglial cells with many diverse supporting roles in the structure, function, and homeostasis of the central nervous system.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding that refers to the presence of a small cell component in a cellular infiltrate.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding that refers to the presence of a small cell component in a cellular infiltrate.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding referring to the presence of necrosis that is confined to a specific anatomic zone.  Representative example is the hepatic zonal necrosis that affects the hepatic parenchyma either in the portal areas or around the hepatic veins.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding referring to the presence of necrosis that is confined to a specific anatomic zone. Representative example is the hepatic zonal necrosis that affects the hepatic parenchyma either in the portal areas or around the hepatic veins.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant brain and spinal cord tumor that arises from glial cells (astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, ependymal cells).  Tumors that arise from astrocytes are called astrocytic tumors or astrocytomas.  Tumors that arise from oligodendrocytes are called oligodendroglial tumors.  Tumors that arise from ependymal cells are called ependymomas. -- 2004:A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant brain and spinal cord tumor that arises from glial cells (astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, ependymal cells). Tumors that arise from astrocytes are called astrocytic tumors or astrocytomas. Tumors that arise from oligodendrocytes are called oligodendroglial tumors. Tumors that arise from ependymal cells are called ependymomas.
A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
